body: Addressed comments and merging due to lazy consensus.

Thanks again for contributing.

I think I'm OK with the implementation you added but could you add an integration test as well? You can probably trigger a 401 that should be handled by your new function in a test in ./gremlin-javascript/src/main/javascript/gremlin-javascript/test/integration/sasl-authentication-tests.js

> Based on information that I've recently read (which could be inaccurate), I think the `SO_KEEPALIVE` option and the `IdleTimeoutHandler` can be used together. TCP probes shouldn't be surfaced by `recv()` so it shouldn't reset the idle timer. If this can be confirmed (via a small test), then I think its probably OK to just add the `SO_KEEPALIVE` option regardless of whether the idle monitor is supported.
> 
> That being said, I'm still a bit skeptical about the real-world usefulness of this PR given that Netty can't control things like keepalive period and so on as those require OS-level options to be set. This just ends up using OS defaults which users may or may not find useful. So while I still support merging this PR, I think it will ultimately be replaced by the idle monitor.
> 
> Again, it would great if you could confirm that setting this option doesn't affect the idle monitor, in which case, you can just always have this option on.

Regarding the scenario of using `SO_KEEPALIVE` and `IdleTimeoutHandler` together, I have conducted a small test. The results show that `SO_KEEPALIVE` does not interfere with `IdleTimeoutHandler` resetting the idle timer. I also studied the source code of IdleTimeoutHandler and related TCP KEEPALIVE documentation. Based on my understanding, as you mentioned, the `SO_KEEPALIVE` feature is a mechanism of the underlying operating system's TCP, and the application layer Netty does not perceive it, so it does not affect IdleTimeoutHandler. My test steps are as follows:

1. In the gremlin-server.yaml configuration file, set `settings.keepAliveInterval` to 60 seconds.
2. Create a client that connects to the gremlin-server using a long-lived connection, without actively releasing the connection, to simulate an idle connection scenario.
3. Observe the time intervals of the `WRITER_IDLE` event logs printed by the gremlin-server. The entire observation period was 8 hours. The results show that the `WRITER_IDLE` event was printed 60 * 8 = 480 times, with a print interval of 60 seconds.

In short, `SO_KEEPALIVE` does not affect IdleTimeoutHandler.

Thanks a lot for confirming.

It would be nice if you could add an entry to the CHANGELOG. If you want, you can also change the code back to the original way you had it since the TCP keepalive can be active together with idle timeout

VOTE +1

Thanks Yang, it's nice to have the changelog cleaned up.
VOTE +1

Thank you!

Thanks for opening the PR @haohao0103, could you expand on your reasons for removing the `@Override` annotation here? This method is overriding the implementation from the [World](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/087b3070914123055d3e4ededc2550f12715a0b4/gremlin-test/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/features/World.java#L89-L91) class

Happy new year. Sorry for the delay in following up on this. I'll take a look at this today.

The test isn't quite what I had in mind. Does your handler only trigger for 500 responses? I thought maybe it could be triggered with a 401 or 403 which is why I was suggesting that the test be placed there. If this isn't the case, and it requires a 500, then it should probably be moved to a different test file as it starts its own server rather than relying on the Gremlin Server that runs for integration tests.
Merging as lazy consensus has been reached.

Understood! It was a few weeks ago and I remember trying to figure out how to get an immediate 4XX status code response from gremlin with a body, but I was unable to invoke that situation at the time. I’ll give it another go, and if it doesn’t work out using the integration test Gremlin Server, I’ll break it out into its own test file.

Do you have any ideas how to immediately get the Gremlin Server to respond with a 4XX or 5XX status code?

Thank you!

Thanks for including the test.

VOTE +1

Hi @KyleBoyer, one easy way to force a 401 response is to adapt a simple test such as [this one](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/169f4a26bfa63752f1c1a425e14beca5c40b226e/gremlin-javascript/src/main/javascript/gremlin-javascript/test/integration/sasl-authentication-tests.js#L46-L55) and just replace the `'password'` in the first line with some invalid junk.

You can also force a 599 status code by putting some junk in the bytecode you are submitting such as 
```
connection.submit(new Bytecode().addStep('notARealStep', []).addStep('tail', []))
```

Thanks for reporting and fixing this bug.

VOTE +1

Thanks for the suggestions - I did try those methods and the Connection.js -> handleMessage is called with the "websocket message", albeit, the error, but still considered a valid websocket response according to the `ws` package. I believe the case I'm trying to cover is invalid responses that are not part of the websocket upgraded connection. I have tried a variety of methods to invoke the unexpected-response handler, but all the following methods all get returned a "valid" websocket message:

- Invalid credentials for sasl authenticator
- Invalid bytecode steps
- Incorrect path `/gremlin` -> `/something-nonexistent` (causes a socket hang up error, so no "unexpected response")

The way we originally encountered this error was by utilizing AWS Neptune, providing invalid credentials, the websocket connection would not be upgraded, and instead we would immediately get a standard 401 reply.

Therefore, I think I will need to break this test out into its own file.

@kenhuuu / @Cole-Greer 

Alright, I have removed the changes to the `sasl-authentication-tests.js` and introduced a new `socket-connection-tests.js`. I have included two tests in this new file, to test for an invalid response with no body, and with a body.

Please let me know how this is looking now, and if any other tweaks should be included.

Thanks again!

I think your latest changes are good enough.

VOTE +1

Would be nice to have a public final String constant for "gremlin-groovy" and "gremlin-lang" somewhere in core so that isn't in so many files.

VOTE +1

> This PR switches the default engine

if this is a switch of the default engine, then why are all the yaml files not modified? https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/tree/master/gremlin-server/conf 

i think there's a lot more documentation changes required as well - is this more of a partial switch in preparation for more work?

Looks good to me as well, thanks for the contribution!

VOTE +1

@spmallette 
> > This PR switches the default engine
> 
> if this is a switch of the default engine, then why are all the yaml files not modified? https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/tree/master/gremlin-server/conf

I've gone ahead and added gremlin-lang without any special configuration in all of the yaml files. It's arguably redundant as gremlin-lang is configured by default in the server `Settings` class in this branch (in place of groovy), however it may be more clear for users to have it explicitly listed in the yaml files.

I left the groovy configuration in all of the yaml files as it's still needed setup `g` and load data.

> i think there's a lot more documentation changes required as well - is this more of a partial switch in preparation for more work?

My goal with this PR is not necessarily about getting rid of groovy as much as it is about making gremlin-lang more prominent. The main driver here is that with the removal of bytecode, the GLVs are generating and sending gremlin-lang scripts. The scripts should be mostly mutually compatible with lang and groovy, however there are potential incompatibilities there and it should not be recommended to execute GraphTraversal generated scripts as groovy.

There is definitely some outstanding future work related to this such as dropping the dependence on groovy to initialize the server This PR captures what I view as the critical piece for the first milestone release which is to prevent users from inadvertently running GraphTraversal generated scripts as groovy.

VOTE +1

It seems like progress on this PR has stalled and it isn't able to pass the smoke tests due to library version convergence issues. More work and testing will need to be done in order to move this through. Is anyone able to help with this? As this PR has been open for a while, if no one is able to help update it in the next week then I think we should close it for the time being until someone is able to work on it.

The only thing that might be a problem is that there may be a small set of users who will now use `globalThis.WebSocket` instead of `ws` since they didn't pass any options. This, however, is probably a very minor concern since the two should be behaviorally the same and underlying _ws isn't exposed.

Thanks for helping to make gremlin-javascript more compatible with later versions of Node.

VOTE +1
thanks - crucial! there is similar need in Gremlin Server
